text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
BURSA
- Bucharest stock exchange stayed close to trading on Tuesday and will reopen on Thursday.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Parliament's lower Chamber of Deputies passed bill granting farmers 500 billion lei to cover losses caused by natural disasters in agricultural year 1995/96.
- Prices of Bucharest housing are expected to rise constantly over next seven years due to shortage.
- Chamber of Deputies will soon take vote on bill on special road fund which will give 1.0 trillion lei to National Road Administration to use for road rehabilitation and construction.
ADEVARUL
- Chamber of Deputies voted against bill on privatisation of commercial banks. Bill will be rediscussed by new parliament after November polls.
TINERETUL LIBER
- National Bank will give troubled banks Banca Dacia Felix SA and Renasterea Creditului Romanesc Credit Bank SA credits to be able to meet individual deposit redemption applications.
General:

- Most newspapers deal with incident two days ago in which ruling Party of Social Democracy (PDSR) was accused of leading a fake opinion survey aimed at shoring up lost electoral ground ahead of November polls.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Eight people were admitted to hospital with meningitis diagnosis in last 24 hours.
ADEVARUL
- Visiting Romanian Foreign Minister Teodor Melescanu will meet U.S. Defence Secretary William Perry to tackle Romania's integration into NATO.
- Chamber of Deputies rejected bill saying assets of children and youth organisations prior to 1989 should be managed by state.
LIBERTATEA
- Opinion poll taken by Urban Sociology Centre shows Romanians like best election campaign of Emil Constantinescu, leader of Democratic Convention main opposition bloc.
- Eugen Radulescu, general manager in National Bank, was appointed Romania's representative to IMF.
CRONICA ROMANA
- Bucharest mayor Victor Ciorbea delivered report on his activity in first 100 days after election in June polls.
CURIERUL NATIONAL

- U.S. Army General George Joulwan, allied commander of NATO forces in Europe, starts visit for talks with Romanian officials on cooperation within Partnership for Peace and NATO-led IFOR peacekeeping mission in Bosnia. ($1.0=3,261 lei)
